title: What are some little known facts about Boston? - Quora

response.answer_text: Q: What are some little known facts about Boston? If you’re younger than 40, it’s possible you’ve never heard of Boston’s infamous Combat Zone, the area designated as its red light district. In the 60s through the early 80s, it was Boston’s equivalent of New York’s Times Square. I will never forget our first drive up Washington Street when I was all of 12-years-old past the strip joints and movie houses, seeing what was probably a prostitute walking up the street with a skirt so short, you could just make out her pubic hairs. My head was pressed to the car window with such force, I’m surprised I didn’t break through it. People may tell you that it’s still legal to bring your cow to graze in Boston Common, but it’s not true. Hey, There's a Cow on the Boston Common The Lagoon Bridge over the pond in Boston Garden was once the world’s shortest suspension bridge. Today, it is supported by girders. The Hancock Tower had a very troubled beginning. Upon the completion of its construction, windows started popping out of the building, crashing to the ground below. If you visited the city in the early 1970s, you would have seen a glass-and-steel skyscraper that looked more like a glass-plywood-and-steel skyscraper. At 50 stories, they called it the “Plywood Skyscraper.” It was discovered that the original design (by I.M. Pei) had window encasements could not properly withstand the stresses of the building as it swayed in the wind. For a while, the builders stationed observers outside the building to watch for a sudden change in the reflection of the glass, which indicated it was about to pop out. Fortunately, no one was hurt.  The old Boston Garden was known for many things, but my favorite was its lack of air conditioning. This meant that whenever the Boston Bruins made it to the playoffs in the late spring months, they teams often had to skate in a fog rising from the ice they could barely keep frozen. It’s incredible to think about this today, but in the mid-1980s, when the city had finally entered its period of revival, you could still park all day in the open lots on Fan Pier for a mere $4. Today, $4 won’t buy you 15 minutes in any downtown garage. Fenway Park used to have a bowling alley, Fenway Bowl. The entrance was on the corner of Lansdale and Brookline Avenue. According to Oliver Jensen in his book History of Railroads of America, a Springfield railroad entrepreneur named Chester Chapin tried to present a proposal to buy a little railroad called the New York Central to Boston banking interests in the years before the Civil War. He failed, of course, but it sets up a wondrous “what if” scenario. That railroad would later be purchased by Cornelius Vanderbilt, which combined with the Erie Canal, would make New York the world’s center of commerce that it is today. One can only imagine how Boston’s fortunes might have changed had Boston’s Brahmins had more vision and less elitism.

Happy Hour is illegal. If you see something that says “happy hour” at a restaurant, they probably just mean the food.Boston Common is the oldest public park in the United States, dating back to 1634, two years before the foundation of Harvard College.The popular snack, the Fig Newton, is named after the Boston suburb of Newton.America`s first-ever chocolate factory opened in Dorchester.Although you could register your vehicle by 1903, Boston didn`t require drivers to obtain a license until 1920.War on Christmas? From 1659–81, English pilgrim law prohibited the celebration of the holiday.15.1% of Bostonians walk to work, the highest percentage of any American city.Boston is not all blue-collar Irish Catholics. A quarter of the city`s residents are foreign born, and half of the students enrolled in Boston public schools either speak a foreign language, or are bilingual.From 1626–30, Boston had only one (1) European settler, William Blackstone. It took the Massachusetts Bay Company four years to establish the city.Popular belief states that Boston`s strange street pattern comes from cow paths. While some of the streets were indeed cow paths, most of the pattern comes from the original coastline of the city, before the expansion projects of the 19th century. This is why downtown Boston`s street plan looks like a modernized colonial layout- it is!
